comments.body: Tell me what you think of my idea.
Seems neat. I think something like this could work well as a new reward for doing something challenging in the End. (not sure what that might be, maybe a new dungeon in addition to the End Cities)

Better to call it "totem of unfalling" or something like this. For balance, it should work ONLY while you holding it in your hand. And after it teleported you to the last block you stood on before falling into the void, it gives you some debaffs: slowness, weakness or blind and baffs: 1-2 extra hearts (absorption), regeneration for 3-10 seconds and slow falling effect for 1-3 minutes. Can be found only (uncraftable) in end cities or how RedSol6419 said: "a new dungeon in addition to the End Cities".
There is Totem of Undying!!! You can't just make something that is similar to an existing item in the Game!

VadimVyat I think it'd be fine if it worked how he's saying, cause if it's a rare end game item (like I suggested) then you would want it to be better than the Elytra for it's one single use of saving you from the void.

And Nightmare71988 it's ok for there to be multiple items that are similar to each other. They added the Crossbow when there was already the bow. And the Conduit when there was already the Beacon. I think it'd be cool to see more Totems in the game. (I will say that the name could use some work though)

You craft it with totem of undying, windcharge, ghast tear and phantom membrane.

When taking damage from the void, it is consumed to give you slowfalling (to cancel your falling speed), levitation (to make you go back up), and regeneration.

Yes. In fact, the new items crafted with the nether items should ALL have different textures. This includes furnaces, crafting tables, and the tools. Blackstone tools should still burn though. Fire resistance is reserved for netherite items.
Es una buena idea para tener espada coló negro hizo herramienta de ese color
Potentially Blackstone tools could have a type of "effect" where they "shoot embers" at mobs, potentially doing miniscule amounts of damage?

I wanted to post the idea for them to have a different texture and to look cool. This texture difference would have also helped with data packs in mini games. But, not burning in lava would also be cool.

Maybe black stone tools can be better than cobblestone but worse than iron since it’s harder to go to the nether than to just get iron. It would be balanced and make people want to make tools out of it with the ability to be fireproof.

I think that tools should have what they are crafted with, shown. For example, if you craft with blackstone to make an ax or pickaxe or sword or any other tool, then instead of it looking like it was made from stone, instead it should look like it was made from blackstone. giving it different properties...would make it better then stone and that is not what they are going for, But just changing the texture to show that they are crafted with blackstone or stone would just be nice.
It cen be interesting if that ever happened. I hope it will be.

but they'd look too much like netherite tools, I say just keep it as stone, after all crimson and warped planks give us brown sticks despite being red/blue but that doesn't mean we need crimson/warped sticks
I completely agree and that anything made from materials in the nether should be fire resistant or float in lava.

It would be nice to have blackstone utensils that don't burn on lava. And for example if I kill a pig there is the percentage that gives me the ribs or the pickaxe that when digging the minerals has a percentage of dropping the ingots without cooking
What’s blackstone?

I think maybe not burning in lava would be cool but does blackstone burn? If so it wouldnt make sense for the tools not to burn. Plus going all the way for a picaxe thats basically stone just fire resistance is a bit underwhelming, i wouldnt mind if stone tools were lost to lava, maybe make them like gold? Fast but not that durable.

What if Blackstone was slightly better than stone gear? A Blackstone furnace could smelt 1.2 times faster than a regular furnace, for example, and a Blackstone pickaxe could have slightly higher durability and slightly higher mining speed, but be able to mine everything a stone pick can mine. It would just be cool to have something that's slightly better than stone, for example a Blackstone blast furnace and a Blackstone smelter could be slightly faster than their stone counterparts. On a slightly off topic note, similar things could also be done with sticks, crafting tables, and chests (eg have dark oak and warped chests, crafting tables, and sticks)
I like the idea but make them the same as stone but with a different texture and maybe fire/explosion proof.

I think you should be able to upgrade your blackstone tools in the smithing table, with a netherite scrap to make them into a new tool. It could be called netherstone, blackite, or rough netherite tools. These would be blackstone mining level still, but as durable as diamond, and would not burn. Also, the blackstone tools should have a different texture, and the rough netherite tools should be colored like the netherite scrap,

Rather than them not burning in lava, they should mine at gold tool speed but have stone tool durability. I think it should be this way because you wouldn't be making stone tools in the nether unless you are speed running or starting in the nether

I had the same idea, I think this would be a great way to get tools and such if you are deep in the nether and your overworld tools have worn out. I also think these tools should have the efficiency of iron tools but the durability of stone tools.

I don't think these should have any special stats, besides maybe fire proofing if they do exist. That way it doesn't remove incentive to move past them and is simply an alternative stone tier with a slight benefit over regular ones while within the nether.

Add Blackstone tier to the game (and a new kind of Furnace)

Why?, you wonder.

Well, Blackstone tools would be a new tier of Tools that would be between Stone and Iron. Blackstone is a volcanic rock, and those types of stone are very resistant (exception is obsidian, but in minecraft the natural laws are differtent than ours).

First, why should be added?

Blackstone tools should be added to give them a difference to Stone ones. Them also would give Minecraft more variety.

Second, what's the advantage to Stone?

Blackstone Tools would mine as faster as Iron, because they are from the Nether. They also would burn in lava, because not all Nether materials need to be inmune to fire or lava.

Third, and the textures? They would be too similar to netherite.

Well, for this part I realize that this part of the idea would be a problem. But Mojang team always find a form to fix problems, and for that I'm relaxed.

Fourth, and the new Furnace?

Well, this furnace would be exactly the same as a normal one, but with the advantage that it would be a Soul Furnace, a furnace that can smelt all smeltable items & blocks, except food or minerals. We all know that Blast Furnaces and Smokers are upgrades for Furnaces, but the Soul Furnaces would be the missing part of smelting upgrade.

Thanks. Those Ideas can be ugraded and don't need to be included at the Nether Update. I hope that everyone would like this.

Items & textures:

- Tools and Soul furnace (I found them on Google Images, and I like the textures)

Ok, I agree it needs a tier. But blackstone tools need to have the same durability and enchantment weight as stone, but the mining speed as iron. I am trying to survive in the nether right now, and I am so tired of having to mine with gold which lasts a few blocks, or mine with stone tools that are as slow as heck. Doing this wouldn’t replace iron, but it would help with trying to live in the nether. Living solely in the nether should be a possibility, and yes it should be hard, but it shouldn’t feel impossible.
Same
It would also make sense the wither skeletons would have blackstone instead of stone swords because there is no regular stone in the nether.
I would like it if blackstone tools had like 10% more durability but slightly slower than normal stone tools.

the issue is simplicity, why add several new textures, items, and tools if they have only one difference and are crafted in like 2 situations, at that point we should have a crafting table for every single wood type despite and clutter the game with birch sticks.

Another way how do to this would be that you can directly place them that way.

Essentially: If you place a stair in a tile to which you stand diagonally, you place on of those. If you target that tile at it's front, it will be an inward bend corner piece, if you target it's back, it will be an outward bend one.

 

+----------------+----------------+

|                     |     target      |

|                     |      tile         |

+----------------+----------------+                           -> corner piece

|     player      |                    |

|                     |                    |

+----------------+----------------+

I feel like to achieve what this post wants, and make it easier for the player to control, it would make more sense to make a tool (eg: a hammer) that's a survival version of the debug stick, that doesn't go thru all blockstates (like waterlogged b/c that wouldn't make sense) only blockstates that are rotations of the current blockstate.

This is a really cool idea! With this I would no longer have to use the debug stick in survival (which is already a bit complicated to use) and it would also give more access to different hitboxes so this could be useful in redstone as well.

Add this to fences, walls, iron bars and glass panels and it will be perfect!
Полностью согласен!

Yes please, there are so many times I wanted a corner block, and it just wouldn't work.

I even tried using the debug stick which would have been enough for me if it worked, but it only rotates the block :(
Yes please this person has articulated exactly how I feel it's easy to just break it and replace it not worth not being able to have it stay a corner when the adjacent block is broken

Another thing that they could add that would achieve similar results (but require a command) would be the ability to use the /fill command (or even add a /place command for placing individual blocks) and manually input the block state in some way - so for stairs, it could be a separate boolean, or you would use something like [“weirdo_direction”=0 , “weirdo_direction”=1] to force a corner stair by inputting two adjacent directions.
Alternatively, just give the debug stick (how does one get it on bedrock btw?) the ability to change the block state of a stair block to a corner stair.

also, I feel like I remember that in a much older version it was possible to get isolated corner stairs by placing a stair to make it a corner, then remove the unnecessary stair block. I’m not sure though.

How powerful are the weapons compared to current ones? How protective are the armor pieces compared to current ones? Are there any special features of steel armor and weapons? If you are proposing adding steel shields, then how would they be different from normal iron shields?

The steel would be 9 armour rating, the sword would also be 6.5 attack damage, 10.5 damage/second (DPS). Durability would be 800, lifetime damage inflicted 6700. Steel would simply have a different look, as an xbox user and pc, it's a tricky one to answer. I wouldn't say there would anything special just a nice fresh look in the armour and weapons area.

The capacity to make steel already exists in the game as steel is just iron with carbon in it. To make steel could require 8 iron ingots and a piece of charcoal or coal to produce 8 steel ingots. Make the dmg/def in between iron and diamond and viola! Steel equipment.

I like the sound of that there are a few mods out there that add steel to java edition but you could also add copper and bronze to the game while at it and once those minerals are added it would open the door to so many other options

the only other thing that would need to be added into the game is carbon and a blast furnace. it can have an interface like a furnace but have two "input" slots. one for iron one for carbon, and then as it is heated it would produce steel. stronger than iron, weaker than diamonds.
I think there should be new ore like steel ore and ruby ore that can be smelted

Estoy de acuerdo, deberían agregar escudos "circulares", mazos de guerra, hachas de doble filo, lanzas, y para agregar más poderes podrían poner runas, con distintos colores y efectos, podrían usar la esmeralda para hacerlas y distintos materiales nuevos, es una idea bastante simple para el gran equipo de Minecraft

More on this with the new blast furnace all they have to do is add carbon for us to get steel. Since coal is already in the game that can be used as carbon to mix with iron and make steel.

With the blast furnace, you put in coal (As the carbon) and combine it with a few pieces of iron to melt together and create Steel. From there you just use steel as if you would iron to create advanced weaponry and tools. Yes, this would replace iron gear and if anything iron stuff should a little weaker if it is eventually added. Things such as "Flint and STEEL" could be updated to be made with steel instead of iron. I believe steel will have a little more armor points than iron armor right now but instead of being really tough it will just have a ton of durability. It will be primarily superior to iron only in the fact that its durability is much higher. I believe that steel should be the opposite of golden gear by having a ton of durability but just be as efficient as iron tools and weapons. That is what will balance Steel out while not just having it as a useless addition.

Steel being added would likely build the path for other alloys and ores to be added to the game such as bronze made of copper and tin. This could be used in the education edition to make people more easily understand metals and alloys on the periodic table too.
That's good we need new armour
idea fantastica!

How about aluminum: only a bit better than gold, except that it gives a speed increase anything from 1% to 20% silver colored ore. Can be dyed/anodized to make it any color.
Or lead, super common ore in some biomes, but weak like gold. Could also apply small speed decrease, and perhaps weak poison when eating wearing armor. Dark grey ore lighter than coal.
Titanium, can only be found in certain biomes, about half way between iron and diamond in strength. Black ore, darker than coal.
Gallium, this ore can be found in small quantities in many biomes, but after being smelted and crafted into blocks, it will melt in about half of the biomes. It can be stored as blocks or like water depending on biome and y height. Ore has water effects like sponge except silver drips. Always liquid in nether. Light Grey ore different pattern.
Mercury, like gallium but always liquid, and if left in your inventory for several in-game days will begin applying poison effects. The duration is up to others for choice. Also you can't just throw it into a chest and then put it right back to cancel poison effects, they will only be canceled if you leave it out of your inventory for at least a day.
Uranium could be added, with a faint pulsing glow and poison effects after so many seconds within a few blocks of it, and death to player after about a minute of direct exposure. You can wear lead armor to carry it without injury. It would power redstone and melt ice.
All metal blocks should transmit redstone signal as long as they touch. Perhaps a stronger redstone signal could be added powerful enough to jump one block gaps of metal. It could also injure players as well.

Steel is the best stuff in the game could be nice and would make sense

Look, my original take on the spear and additions I made to the trident were too similar to what's here, so it got deleted, and I was told to move it to the similar post. Because I found several posts, I'm also gonna go over my problems with each of the original suggestions at the beginning of them.

 

I get that bamboo needs more use, but this isn't how spears should be made. Bamboos have been proven to be worth half that sticks are, so a spear made out of a bamboo would actually only be as long as half a sword. Plus, in order to make spears a viable weapon, they cant just be made to be so weak.

Heres my take:

Description: The spear can be used as both a ranged and melee weapon.

  1. Type: Combat
  2. Durability: 125
  3. Renewable: Yes
  4. Stackable: No
  5. Sounds: Shoot (Twang is louder and longer.)

Obtaining:

  • Crafting: The spear is made from 2 sticks topped with flint. It has lowered durability due to the cheap materials it is made from. It can also be crafted by combining two broken spears to combine their durability.

Usage:

  • Melee - There are technically two ways to hit people with the spear.
    • Standard - Whacking someone with a spear in the same way you would a sword would only deal 4 damage, and take double durability.
    • Charging - When running, the spear would be held in both hands, level with the target, and if you hit someone with it in this state, it is thrust forward and deals a high critical hit, about 8 or more damage. Critical hits are not rewarded for jump attacks. Jumping while sprinting actually negates the charging effect. If a player is sprinting, then suddenly switches to throw instead of melee, 5% more time is added to the pullback.
  • Ranged - By using, the spear is pulled back, and when it is released, thrown far. Look, it's all the same deal as the trident, ok? It can even be thrown into the water and keep going, making it viable in as well as out of land.
  • Dusting and tracking - The trident can be crafted with one glowstone dust to cast the spectral effect upon it. The first time it hits someone, they will be dealt with a very brief spectral effect, and the spear will go back to normal.
  • Enchantments -  Shown below.
  1. Impaling [Levels - 5]: Known enchant. Damage is only added to charging and throwing.
  2. Ignition [Levels - 1]: Thrown spears ignite and deal fire damage to those it hits. The effect is lost in rain and water.
  3. Loyalty [Levels - 3]: Known enchant.
  4. Infinity [Levels - 1]: Known enchant.
  5. Unbreaking [Levels - 3]: Known enchant.
  6. Mending [Levels - 1]: Known enchant. This enchantment has +50% the effect on this weapon than it does on other weapons.
  7. Curse of Vanishing: Known enchant.

In-Game Application: The spear itself as an item grants the ability to try out the mechanics of a duel melee-ranged weapon. The weapons very early accessibility is limited by its low durability and opportunity of use. There's also a sort of primitive theme to it. I don't suggest the use of iron spears to give it a very concrete and distinguished place in the game.

As a weapon, it is made viable by the mechanics I've added to the core of it and the trident. If you care enough to enchant one, you must love the hit and run strategy of it enough to put more work into it. It may even be made more viable than the trident to some, as the Spear can be used in all situations, but the trident is better during storms and in water.

My biggest point (pun not intended) to be made here was the charging aspect. Instead of jumping in order to obtain a critical hit, you would have to run at your opponent. The concept would also apply to the trident as well as the spear, with its normal damage being lowered, and the crit damage being raised. This might make the trident just as viable a weapon as a normal diamond sword, and encourages skill for reward.

When charging, a trident is held outwards with only one hand, like a gladiator. Damage will also have to be adjusted for this weapon as well, maybe up to 10 or 11 damage when charging.

As a final note, I would also like to suggest the idea that when loyalty is used in conjunction with mending, every time half of the spear or tridents durability has been renewed, the loyalty level goes up (capping at 3), as it becomes more loyal to the player. I'm not as attached to this idea, as it can be easily overruled by simply enchanting it better, but it's still worth pointing out here.

Thank you for considering my suggestion. More to come.

There's no way on java but on other editions use a hopper clock with dispensers.

In addition to being able to loop the song, it would be really great to also allow some play/pause functionality via redstone and maybe read out the progress of the played audio via a comparator. Right now, the comparator will output the ID of the disc inserted, which is not bad but also not really useful at the same time.

My vision is the following:

1) if the jukebox is not playing, powering it will cause the song to start playing if any disk is inserted
2) a comparator outputs signal strength according to how far the song has progressed (0 at the beginning, 15 when it is finished)
note: with 1 and 2 combined, you can already implement looping (just trigger the jukebox when the output reaches 15)
3) when the jukebox is playing a song, powering it will pause the track. the jukebox should remember where it left off and continue playing at that position, unless the disk is taken out.

This would allow for really good control over the music. Also, Jukeboxes should work with dispensers and hoppers to allow changing out discs automatically, but that is already proposed in another suggestion: https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360028758251-Jukebox-hoppers-

So this has been added, and they're really cool and stylish, but there's a disparity in font size and character limit between editions.

This isn't an easy fix, as smaller text allows more information to be conveyed but also makes it harder to resolve that information at a distance.

I propose that these signs, since they are already more dynamic than traditional signs, would benefit from more dynamic text.

I suggest that the character limit is increased to 8, to match standard signs, but that the font size depends on the number of characters and lines used.

8 or fewer characters on any one line: bedrock font size
6 or fewer characters on any one line: java font size
4 or fewer characters on two or fewer lines: large font
2 or fewer characters on one line: extra large font

Additionally lines would be vertically justified, and spaces would count towards letter and line count.

This increases readability for small signs in a simple way that can be easily made consistent for newer players. It also allows for British-pub style single-letter signs (visible at great distance) or even hanging banners.

There is a possible issue of censoring banners, but it might be possible to detect the letters of adjacent signs when placing them if deemed necessary.

Part of what makes Minecraft so great is the low resolution.  Raising the resolution of Minecraft lowers the greatness.  Stairs and slabs would work fine.

I'm not convinced that anything smaller than half slabs is suitable for vanilla Minecraft, which is how the developers appear to feel, also. However, the style of implementation here is indeed tasteful.
It should be called half quarter blocks then. We already have half blocks, they're called slabs

Bilbo Baggins, this doesn't really change the resolution available, just gives more options within the current resolution.  You can already use slabs and stairs (where available) to work at this resolution.  The issue is that they aren't available nearly as widely as they should be.  They also have relatively arbitrary limitations, like not being able to place slabs vertically.

 

MacchuPicchu, thanks for commenting.  I did try to limit this to a very vanilla feel, which is why I specifically only allowed the same kind of material in one block space.  It's an existing mechanic with slabs, so I suspect that would be a lot easier to implement.

 

AhmetCavus, those are just known as slabs.  They are half blocks, but only in one dimension.  These are half blocks in all dimensions (half a meter on all sides), and so the name fits.  Although if the developers want to call them something else if they choose to implement this, that is always their right.

I still think it raises the resolution.  Little blocks would be smaller than regular blocks.  I can just see this opening up cans of worms such as little slabs and little stairs, and then the resolution of Minecraft really starts to degrade.

I really don't think the slippery slope applies here.  They aren't really blocks in their own right, they're components.  It wouldn't make sense to have stair versions of these because then you couldn't use them to put together a full block.

Remember that it's always Mojang's decision to add something to the game.  I agree that slabs and stairs that are that small wouldn't fit in the game, and I believe that they would also think so.
